Chaplin exercised complete control over his pictures,to the extent that he would act out the other roles for his cast, expecting them to imitate him exactly.Bloom, p. 101; Brownlow, pp. 59, 98, 138, 154; Robinson, p. 614.He personally edited all of his films, trawling through the large amounts of footage to create the exact picture he wanted.Robinson, pp. 140, 235, 236.As a result of his complete independence, he was identified by the film historianAndrew Sarrisas one of the firstauteurfilmmakers.Maland (1989), p. 353.Chaplin did receive help, notably from his long-time cinematographerRoland Totheroh, brother Sydney Chaplin, and variousassistant directorssuch asHarry CrockerandCharles Reisner.cite webhttp://chaplin.bfi.org.uk/programme/essays/collaborators.htmlChaplin's writing and directing collaboratorsBritish Film Institute27 June 2012
article.heading: Style and themes

link.part: A collection of scenes from ''The Kid (1921 film)The Kid'' (1921), demonstrating Chaplin's mixture of slapstick, pathos, and social commentary

article.paragraph: While Chaplin's comedic style is broadly defined asslapstick,Robinson, p. 212.it is considered restrained and intelligent,Brownlow, p. 30.with the film historian Philip Kemp describing his work as a mix of "deft, balletic physical comedy and thoughtful, situation-based gags".Kemp, p. 63.Chaplin diverged from conventional slapstick by slowing the pace and exhausting each scene of its comic potential, with more focus on developing the viewer's relationship to the characters.Mast, pp. 8392.Unlike conventional slapstick comedies, Robinson states that the comic moments in Chaplin's films centre on the Tramp's attitude to the things happening to him: the humour does not come from the Tramp bumping into a tree, but from his lifting his hat to the tree in apology.Dan Kamin writes that Chaplin's "quirky mannerisms" and "serious demeanour in the midst of slapstick action" are other key aspects of his comedy,Kamin, pp. 67.while the surreal transformation of objects and the employment ofIn-camera effectin-cameratrickery are also common features.Mast, pp. 8392; Kamin, pp. 3334.

Chaplin's silent films typically follow the Tramp's efforts to survive in a hostile world.Louvish, p. 60.The character lives in poverty and is frequently treated badly, but remains kind and upbeat;Kemp, p. 63; Robinson, pp. 211, 352; Hansmeyer, p. 4.defying his social position, he strives to be seen as a gentleman.Robinson, p. 203.As Chaplin said in 1925, "The whole point of the Little Fellow is that no matter how down on his ass he is, no matter how well the jackals succeed in tearing him apart, he's still a man of dignity."Weissman (2009), p. 47.The Tramp defies authority figuresDale, p. 17.and "gives as good as he gets",leading Robinson and Louvish to see him as a representative for the underprivileged an "everymanturned heroic saviour".Robinson, pp. 455, 485; Louvish, p. 138 (for quote).Hansmeyer notes that several of Chaplin's films end with "the homeless and lonely Tramp [walking] optimistically ... into the sunset ... to continue his journey".Hansmeyer, p. 4.

template.arg: "It is paradoxical that tragedy stimulates the spirit of ridicule ... ridicule, I suppose, is an attitude of defiance; we must laugh in the face of our helplessness against the forces of nature – or go insane."<ref name
—Chaplin explaining why his comedies often make fun of tragic circumstances

article.paragraph: The infusion ofpathosis a well-known aspect of Chaplin's work,Dale, pp. 9, 19, 20; Louvish, p. 203.and Larcher notes his reputation for "[inducing] laughter and tears".Larcher, p. 75.Sentimentality in his films come from a variety of sources, with Louvish pinpointing "personal failure, society's strictures, economic disaster, and the elements."Louvish, p. 204.Chaplin sometimes drew on tragic events when creating his films, as in the case ofThe Gold Rush(1925), which was inspired by the fate of the Donner Party.Robinson, pp. 334335.Constance B. Kuriyama has identified serious underlying themes in the early comedies, such as greed (The Gold Rush) and loss (The Kid).Kuriyama, p. 31.Chaplin also touched on controversial issues: immigration (The Immigrant, 1917); illegitimacy (The Kid, 1921); and drug use (Easy Street, 1917).He often explored these topics ironically, making comedy out of suffering.Louvish, pp. 137, 145.

Social commentary was a feature of Chaplin's films from early in his career, as he portrayed the underdog in a sympathetic light and highlighted the difficulties of the poor.Robinson, p. 599.Later, as he developed a keen interest in economics and felt obliged to publicise his views,Robinson, p. 456.Chaplin began incorporating overtly political messages into his films.Maland (1989), p. 159.Modern Times(1936) depicted factory workers in dismal conditions,The Great Dictator(1940) parodiedAdolf HitlerandBenito Mussoliniand ended in a speech against nationalism,Monsieur Verdoux(1947) criticised war and capitalism, andA King in New York(1957) attackedMcCarthyism.Larcher, pp. 6289.

Several of Chaplin's films incorporate autobiographical elements, and the psychologistSigmund Freudbelieved that Chaplin "always plays only himself as he was in his dismal youth".Weissmann (1999), pp. 439445.The Kidis thought to reflect Chaplin's childhood trauma of being sent into an orphanage,the main characters inLimelight(1952) contain elements from the lives of his parents,Bloom, p. 107.andA King in New Yorkreferences Chaplin's experiences of being shunned by the United States.Robinson, pp. 588589.Many of his sets, especially in street scenes, bear a strong similarity to Kennington, where he grew up.Stephen M. Weissmanhas argued that Chaplin's problematic relationship with his mentally ill mother was often reflected in his female characters and the Tramp's desire to save them.

Regarding the structure of Chaplin's films, the scholarGerald Mastsees them as consisting of sketches tied together by the same theme and setting, rather than having a tightly unified storyline.Mast, pp. 123128.Visually, his films are simple and economic,Louvish, p. 298; Robinson, p. 592.with scenes portrayed as if set on a stage.Epstein, pp. 8485; Mast, pp. 8392; Louvish, p. 185.His approach to filming was described by the art directorEugne Louri: "Chaplin did not think in 'artistic' images when he was shooting. He believed that action is the main thing. The camera is there to photograph the actors".Robinson, p. 565.In his autobiography, Chaplin wrote, "Simplicity is best ... pompous effects slow up action, are boring and unpleasant ... The camera should not intrude."Chaplin, p. 250.This approach has prompted criticism, since the 1940s, for being "old fashioned",Brownlow, p. 91; Louvish, p. 298, Kamin, p. 35.while the film scholar Donald McCaffrey sees it as an indication that Chaplin never completely understood film as a medium.McCaffrey, pp. 8295.Kamin, however, comments that Chaplin's comedic talent would not be enough to remain funny on screen if he did not have an "ability to conceive and direct scenes specifically for the film medium".Kamin, p. 29.
article.heading: Composing
article.paragraph: Chaplin developed a passion for music as a child, and taught himself to play the piano, violin, and cello.Robinson, p. 411; Louvish, pp. 1718.He considered the musical accompaniment of a film to be important,and fromA Woman of Parisonwards he took an increasing interest in this area.Robinson, p. 411.With the advent of sound technology, Chaplin began using a synchronised orchestral soundtrack composed by himself forCity Lights(1931). He thereafter composed the scores for all of his films, and from the late 1950s to his death, he scored all of his silent features and some of his short films.Vance, Jeffrey. "Introduction." James, Eric. Making Music with Charlie Chaplin. Lanham, MD: Scarecrow Press, p. xiii. ISBN 0-8108-3741-2

As Chaplin was not a trained musician, he could not read sheet music and needed the help of professional composers, such asDavid Raksin,Raymond RaschandEric James, when creating his scores. Although some critics have claimed that credit for his film music should be given to the composers who worked with him, Raksin who worked with Chaplin onModern Timeshas stressed Chaplin's creative position and active participation in the composing process.Raksin and Berg, pp. 4750.This process, which could take months, would start with Chaplin describing to the composer(s) exactly what he wanted and singing or playing tunes he had improvised on the piano.These tunes were then developed further in a close collaboration among the composer(s) and Chaplin.According to film historianJeffrey Vance, "although he relied upon associates to arrange varied and complex instrumentation, the musical imperative is his, and not a note in a Chaplin musical score was placed there without his assent."Vance, Jeffrey (4 August 2003). "Chaplin the Composer: An Excerpt from Chaplin: Genius of the Cinema".VarietySpecial Advertising Supplement, pp. 2021.

Chaplin's compositions produced three popular songs. "Smile (Charlie Chaplin song)Smile", composed originally forModern Times(1936) and later set to lyrics byJohn Turner (lyricist)John TurnerandGeoffrey Parsons (lyricist)Geoffrey Parsons, was a hit forNat King Colein 1954.ForLimelight, Chaplin composed "Terry's Theme", which was popularised byJimmy Young (disc jockey)Jimmy Youngas "Eternally (1952 song)Eternally" (1952).Kamin, p. 198.Finally, "This Is My Song (1967 song)This Is My Song", performed byPetula ClarkforA Countess from Hong Kong(1967), reached number one on the UK and other European charts.Hennessy, Mike (22 April 1967). "Chaplin's 'Song' Catches Fire in Europe".Billboard, p. 60.Chaplin also received his only competitive Oscar for his composition work, as theLimelighttheme won anAcademy Award for Best Original Scorein 1973 following the film's re-release.refn<arg name="Although the film had originally been released in 1952, it did not play for one week in Los Angeles because of its boycott, and thus did not meet the criterion for nomination until it was re-released in 1972.{{cite web|last">Weston|firstnote
article.heading: Legacy

link.part: Chaplin asthe Trampin 1915, cinema's "most universal icon"Sarris, p. 139.

article.paragraph: In 1998, the film criticAndrew Sarriscalled Chaplin "arguably the single most important artist produced by the cinema, certainly its most extraordinary performer and probably still its most universal icon".He is described by the British Film Institute as "a towering figure in world culture",cite webhttp://chaplin.bfi.org.uk/Charlie ChaplinBritish Film InstituteCharlie Chaplin7 October 2012and was included inTime (magazine)Timemagazine's list of the "Time 100: The Most Important People of the Century100 Most Important People of the 20th Century" for the "laughter [he brought] to millions" and because he "more or less invented global recognizability and helped turn an industry into an art".cite newsTIME 100: Charlie Chaplinhttp://www.time.com/time/time100/artists/profile/chaplin.htmlhttps://web.archive.org/web/20110523194732/http://www.time.com/time/time100/artists/profile/chaplin.html23 May 2011Time MagazineJoshuaQuittner8 June 199811 November 2013

The image of the Tramp has become a part of cultural history;Hansmeyer, p. 3.according to Simon Louvish, the character is recognisable to people who have never seen a Chaplin film, and in places where his films are never shown.Louvish, p. xvii.The criticLeonard Maltinhas written of the "unique" and "indelible" nature of the Tramp, and argued that no other comedian matched his "worldwide impact".cite webhttp://blogs.indiewire.com/leonardmaltin/chaplinfirst_last_and_alwaysChaplin – First, Last, And AlwaysIndiewire7 October 2012Praising the character,Richard Schickelsuggests that Chaplin's films with the Tramp contain the most "eloquent, richly comedic expressions of the human spirit" in movie history.Schickel, p. 41.Memorabilia connected to the character still fetches large sums in auctions: in 2006 a bowler hat and a bamboo cane that were part of the Tramp's costume were bought for $140,000 in a Los Angeles auction.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/5116474.stmRecord price for Chaplin hat setBBC7 October 2012

As a filmmaker, Chaplin is considered a pioneer and one of the most influential figures of the early twentieth century.He is often credited as one of the medium's first artists.Schickel, pp. 34; Cousins, p. 36; Robinson, pp. 209211; Kamin, p. xiv.Film historianMark Cousins (film critic)Mark Cousinshas written that Chaplin "changed not only the imagery of cinema, but also its sociology and grammar" and claims that Chaplin was as important to the development of comedy as a genre asD.W. Griffithwas to drama.Cousins, p. 70He was the first to popularise feature-length comedy and to slow down the pace of action, adding pathos and subtlety to it.Schickel, pp. 7, 13.Cite episodeCharlie ChaplinSilent ClownsPresented by [[Paul Merton]], directed by Tom Cholmondeley[[British Broadcasting Corporation]][[BBC Four]]1 June 2006Although his work is mostly classified as slapstick, Chaplin's dramaA Woman of Paris(1923) was a major influence onErnst Lubitsch's filmThe Marriage Circle(1924) and thus played a part in the development of "sophisticated comedy".Thompson, pp. 398399; Robinson, p. 321, Louvish, p. 185.According to David Robinson, Chaplin's innovations were "rapidly assimilated to become part of the common practice of film craft."Robinson, p. 321.Filmmakers who cited Chaplin as an influence includeFederico Fellini(who called Chaplin "a sort ofAdam, from whom we are all descended"),Jacques Tati("Without him I would never have made a film"),Ren Clair ("He inspired practically every filmmaker"),Michael Powell,Brownlow, p. 77.Billy Wilder,Cite episodeEpisode 2[[The Story of Film: An Odyssey]][[Mark Cousins (film critic)|Mark Cousins]][[Channel 4]][[More4]]10 September 201127:51–28:35Vittorio De Sica,Cardulo, pp. 16, 212.andRichard Attenborough.cite webAttenborough introductionhttp://chaplin.bfi.org.uk/programme/attenborough.htmlCharlie ChaplinBritish Film Institute11 February 2013Russian filmmakerAndrei Tarkovskypraised Chaplin as "the only person to have gone down into cinematic history without any shadow of a doubt. The films he left behind can never grow old."cite journalTarkovsky's ChoiceLasica, Tom[[Sight & Sound]]March 199333[[British Film Institute]]http://people.ucalgary.ca/~tstronds/nostalghia.com/TheTopics/Tarkovsky-TopTen.html1 February 2014

Chaplin also strongly influenced the work of later comedians.Marcel Marceausaid he was inspired to become a mime artist after watching Chaplin,while the actorRaj Kapoorbased his screen persona on the Tramp.Mark Cousins has also detected Chaplin's comedic style in the French characterMonsieur Hulotand the Italian characterTot.In other fields, Chaplin helped inspire the cartoon charactersFelix the CatCanemaker, pp. 38, 78.andMickey Mouse,Jackson, pp. 439444.and was an influence on theDadaart movement.Simmons, pp. 811.As one of the founding members of United Artists, Chaplin also had a role in the development of the film industry. Gerald Mast has written that although UA never became a major company likeMGMorParamount Pictures, the idea that directors could produce their own films was "years ahead of its time".Mast, p. 100.

In the 21st century, several of Chaplin's films are still regarded as classics and among the greatest ever made. The 2012Sight & Soundpoll, which compiles "top ten" ballots from film critics and directors to determine each group's most acclaimed films,sawCity Lightsrank among the critics' top 50,Modern Timesinside the top 100, andThe Great DictatorandThe Gold Rushplaced in the top 250.cite webThe Greatest Films Poll: Critics Top 250 Filmshttp://explore.bfi.org.uk/sightandsoundpolls/2012/critics/Sight & SoundBritish Film Institute31 January 2013The top 100 films as voted on by directors includedModern Timesat number 22,City Lightsat number 30, andThe Gold Rushat number 91.cite webDirectors' Top 100 Filmshttp://explore.bfi.org.uk/sightandsoundpolls/2012/directors/British Film Institute8 February 2013Every one of Chaplin's features received a vote.cite webThe Greatest Films Poll: All FilmsSight & Soundhttp://explore.bfi.org.uk/sightandsoundpolls/2012/filmBritish Film Institute31 January 2013In 2007, theAmerican Film InstitutenamedCity Lightsthe 11thAFI's 100 Years...100 Movies (10th Anniversary Edition)greatest American film of all time, whileThe Gold RushandModern Timesagain ranked in the top 100.cite webAFI's 100 Years ... 100 Movies – 10th Anniversary Editionhttp://www.afi.com/100Years/movies10.aspxAmerican Film Institute8 February 2013Books about Chaplin continue to be published regularly, and he is a popular subject for media scholars and film archivists.Louvish, p. xvi; Maland pp. xi, 359, 370.Many of Chaplin's film have had aDVDandBlu-Rayrelease.cite webDVDs, United Stateshttp://www.charliechaplin.com/en/us/dvdsCharlie Chaplin23 December 2013cite webDVDs, United Kingdomhttp://www.charliechaplin.com/en/uk/dvdsCharlie Chaplin23 December 2013
article.heading: Commemoration and tributes
article.paragraph: Several memorials have been dedicated to Chaplin. In his home city, theLondon Film Museumhosts a permanent exhibition on his life and career calledCharlie Chaplin The Great Londoner, which opened in 2010.cite webhttp://www.londonfilmmuseum.com/south-bank/about-us/London Film Museum: About UsLondon Film Museum22 July 2012A statue of Chaplin as the Tramp is located inLeicester Square, sculpted byJohn Doubledayand unveiled in 1981.Robinson, p. 677.The city also includes a road named after him, "Charlie Chaplin Walk" in central London, which is the location of theBFI IMAX.cite webWelcome to IMAX United Kingdomhttps://www.imax.com/countries/gb/IMAX22 December 2013https://web.archive.org/web/20150604110826/https://www.imax.com/countries/gb/4 June 2015no

Chaplin's final home, Manoir de Ban in Corsier-sur-Vevey, Switzerland, is in the process of being converted into a museum, to be opened in 2016, exploring his life and career.cite webhttp://www.chaplinmuseum.com/en/index.phpChaplin's World: The Modern Times MuseumChaplin Museum Development SA29 March 2013The nearby town ofVeveynamed a park in his honour in 1980 and erected a statue there in 1982.In 2011, two large murals depicting Chaplin on two 14-storey buildings were also unveiled in Vevey.cite webhttp://www.rts.ch/info/suisse/3490412-vevey-les-tours-chaplin-ont-ete-inaugurees.htmlVevey: les tours "Chaplin" ont été inaugurées8 October 2011RTS.ch22 July 2012(In French)Chaplin has also been honoured by the Irish town ofWaterville, County KerryWaterville, where he spent several summers with his family in the 1960s. A statue was erected in 1998,cite webhttp://visitwaterville.ie/charlie-chaplin/Charlie ChaplinVisitWaterville.ie22 July 2012and since 2011 the town has been host to the annual Charlie Chaplin Comedy Film Festival, which was founded to celebrate Chaplin's legacy and to showcase new comic talent.cite webhttp://chaplinfilmfestival.com/the-story/The StoryCharlie Chaplin Comedy Film Festival22 July 2012

In other tributes, aminor planet,3623 Chaplindiscovered bySoviet UnionSovietastronomerLyudmila Karachkinain 1981 is named after Chaplin.Schmadel, p. 305.Throughout the 1980s, the Tramp image was used byIBMto advertise their personal computers.Maland (1989), pp. 362370.Chaplin's 100th birthday anniversary in 1989 was marked with several events around the world,refn<arg name="On his birthday, 16 April, ''City Lights'' was screened at a gala at the [[Dominion Theatre]] in London, the site of its British premiere in 1931.{{cite news|url">https://news.google.com/newspapers?nidnoteand on 15 April 2011, a day before his 122nd birthday,Googlecelebrated him with a specialGoogle Doodlevideo on its global and other country-wide homepages.cite webGoogle doodles a video honouring Charlie Chaplinhttp://www.ibnlive.com/news/india/google-doodles-a-video-honouring-charlie-chaplin-366297.html[[CNN-IBN|IBN Live]]15 April 2011Many countries, spanning six continents, have honoured Chaplin with a postal stamp.cite webCharlie Chaplin Stampshttp://chaplinstamps.blogspot.co.uk/Blogger8 February 2013

Chaplin's legacy is managed on behalf of his children by the Chaplin office, located in Paris. The office represents Association Chaplin, founded by some of his children "to protect the name, image and moral rights" to his body of work, Roy Export SAS, which owns the copyright to most of his films made after 1918, and Bubbles Incorporated S.A., which owns the copyrights to his image and name.cite webhttp://www.charliechaplin.com/fr/contacts/articles/148-Association-ChaplinAssociation ChaplinAssociation Chaplin13 July 2013;cite webhttp://thelittlefellow.org/interview3.htmlInterview with Kate GuyonvarchLisa K. Stein24 July 2013Their central archive is held at the archives ofMontreux, Switzerland and scanned versions of its contents, including 83,630 images, 118 scripts, 976 manuscripts, 7,756 letters, and thousands of other documents, are available for research purposes at the Chaplin Research Centre at theCineteca di Bologna.cite webhttp://chaplin.bfi.org.uk/resources/worldwide/chaplin-archive.htmlChaplin ArchiveBritish Film Institute11 December 2014;cite webCharlie Chaplin Archivehttp://www.charliechaplinarchive.org/sito/cerca/596/Cineteca Bologna11 February 2013The photographic archive, which includes approximately 10,000 photographs from Chaplin's life and career, is kept at theMuse de l'ElyseinLausanne,Switzerland.cite webhttp://www.elysee.ch/en/collections/chaplin-at-the-musee-de-lelysee/Chaplin at the Musée de l'ElyséeMusée de l'Elysée12 July 2013https://web.archive.org/web/20131105223440/http://www.elysee.ch/en/collections/chaplin-at-the-musee-de-lelysee/5 November 2013The British Film Institute has also established the Charles Chaplin Research Foundation, and the first international Charles Chaplin Conference was held in London in July 2005.cite webThe BFI Charles Chaplin Conference July 2005http://chaplin.bfi.org.uk/programme/conference/Charlie ChaplinBritish Film Institute11 February 2013

article.heading: Characterisations
article.paragraph: Chaplin is the subject of abiographical film,Chaplin (film)Chaplin(1992) directed byRichard Attenborough, and starringRobert Downey, Jr.in the title role.cite webRobert Downey, Jr. profile, Finding Your Rootshttp://www.pbs.org/weta/finding-your-roots/profiles/robert-downey-jr/PBS9 February 2013He is also a character in theperiod dramafilmThe Cat's Meow(2001), played byEddie Izzard, and in theMade-for-TV moviemade-for-television movieThe Scarlett O'Hara War(1980), played byClive Revill.cite newsThe Cat's Meow – Casthttp://www.nytimes.com/movies/movie/251894/The-Cat-s-Meow/castThe New York Times9 November 2013cite newsThe Scarlett O'Hara War – Casthttp://www.nytimes.com/movies/movie/128737/The-Scarlett-O-Hara-War/cast9 November 2013A television series about Chaplin's childhood,Young Charlie Chaplin, ran onPBSin 1989, and was nominated for anEmmy Awardfor Outstanding Children's Program.cite webYoung Charlie Chaplin Wonderworkshttp://www.emmys.com/shows/young-charlie-chaplin-wonderworksEmmys9 November 2013

Chaplin's life has also been the subject of several stage productions. Two musicals,Little TrampandChaplin (1993 musical)Chaplin, were produced in the early 1990s. In 2006,Thomas Meehan (writer)Thomas Meehanand Christopher Curtis created another musical,Limelight: The Story of Charlie Chaplin, which was first performed at theLa Jolla Playhousein San Diego in 2010.cite webhttp://www.lajollaplayhouse.org/the-season/2010-2011-season/limelightLimelight – The Story of Charlie ChaplinLa Jolla Playhouse25 June 2012https://web.archive.org/web/20130721141919/http://www.lajollaplayhouse.org/the-season/2010-2011-season/limelight21 July 2013It was adapted forBroadway theatreBroadwaytwo years later, re-titledChaplin A Musical.cite webhttp://chaplinbroadway.com/Chaplin – A MusicalBarrymore Theatre25 June 2012yeshttps://web.archive.org/20120615070714/http://www.chaplinbroadway.com:80/15 June 2012Chaplin was portrayed by Robert McClure in both productions. In 2013, two plays about Chaplin premiered inFinland:Chaplinat theSvenska Teatern,cite webOhjelmisto: Chaplinhttp://www.svenskateatern.fi/fi/ohjelmisto/ohjelmisto/chaplin/Svenska Teatern8 February 2013andKulkuri(The Tramp) at theTampere Workers' Theatre.cite webKulkurihttp://www.ttt-teatteri.fi/ohjelmisto/kulkuriTampereen Työväen Teatteri2 October 2013Chaplin has also been characterised inliterary fiction, as the central character inGlen David Gold'sSunnyside (novel)Sunnyside(2009), anovelset in theFirst World Warperiod.cite newshttp://www.theguardian.com/books/2009/jun/27/sunnyside-glen-gold-charlie-chaplinNess, PatrickLooking for the Little TrampThe Guardian27 June 200925 June 2012
article.heading: Awards and recognition

link.part: Chaplin's star on theHollywood Walk of Fame, located at 6755 Hollywood Boulevard. Although the project started in 1958, Chaplin only received his star in 1970 because of his political views.

article.paragraph: Chaplin received many awards and honours, especially later in life. In the1975 New Year Honours, he was appointed aKnight Commander of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire.cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/march/4/newsid_2794000/2794107.stmComic genius Chaplin is knightedBBC15 February 20104 March 1975http://www.webcitation.org/5uKhpymXs18 November 2010noHe was also awarded honoraryDoctor of Lettersdegrees by the University of Oxford and the University of Durham in 1962.In 1965 he andIngmar Bergmanwere joint winners of theErasmus PrizeRobinson, p. 610.and in 1971 he was appointed a Commander of the National Order of the Legion of Honour by the French government.cite webhttp://www.festival-cannes.com/en/article/57899.htmlTribute to Charlie ChaplinFestival de Cannes25 June 2012

From the film industry, Chaplin received a specialGolden Lionat the Venice Film Festival in 1972,Robinson, pp. 625626.and a Lifetime Achievement Award from theLincoln Center Film Societythe same year. The latter has since been presented annually to filmmakers as The Chaplin Award.cite webhttp://www.filmlinc.com/blog/entry/the-birth-of-the-chaplin-award40 Years Ago–The Birth of the Chaplin AwardLincoln Center Film Society30 March 2012E. Segal, Martin25 June 2012https://web.archive.org/web/20120502165257/http://www.filmlinc.com/blog/entry/the-birth-of-the-chaplin-award2 May 2012Chaplin was given a star on theHollywood Walk of Famein 1972, having been previously excluded because of his political beliefs.Williams, p. 311.

Chaplin received threeAcademy Awards: anAcademy Honorary AwardHonorary Awardfor "versatility and genius in acting, writing, directing, and producingThe Circus" in 1929,a second Honorary Award for "the incalculable effect he has had in making motion pictures the art form of this century" in 1972,and aAcademy Award for Best Original ScoreBest Scoreaward in 1973 forLimelight(shared with Ray Rasch and Larry Russell).He was further nominated in theAcademy Award for Best ActorBest Actor,Academy Award for Best Original ScreenplayBest Original Screenplay, andAcademy Award for Best PictureBest Picture(as producer) categories forThe Great Dictator, and received another Best Original Screenplay nomination forMonsieur Verdoux.cite webhttp://www.oscars.org/oscars/ceremonies/1941The 13th Academy Awards: Nominees and WinnersAcademy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences25 June 2012https://web.archive.org/web/20120303110034/http://www.oscars.org/awards/academyawards/legacy/ceremony/13th-winners.html3 March 2012

Six of Chaplin's films have been selected for preservation in theNational Film Registryby the United StatesLibrary of Congress:The Immigrant(1917),The Kid(1921),The Gold Rush(1925),City Lights(1931),Modern Times(1936), andThe Great Dictator(1940).cite webNational Film Registryhttp://www.loc.gov/film/registry_titles.php?Library of Congress5 November 2013https://web.archive.org/web/20130328133050/http://www.loc.gov/film/registry_titles.php?28 March 2013no
